metadata.title: Recent Advances of 2D Nanomaterials in the electrode materials of Lithium-Ion Batteries

Article Title: Recent Advances of 2D Nanomaterials in the electrode materials of Lithium-Ion Batteries
Author(s): Xiaobei Zang, Teng Wang, Zhiyuan Han, Lingtong Li, Xin Wu
DOI: 10.1142/S1793292019300019
Received: 11 October 2018
Accepted: 09 January 2019
To be cited as: Xiaobei Zang et al., Recent Advances of 2D Nanomaterials in the electrode materials of Lithium-Ion Batteries, NANO, doi: 10.1142/S1793292019300019
Link to final version: https://doi.org/10.1142/S1793292019300019

The manuscript will be copyedited, typeset and proofread before it is released in the final form. As a result, the published copy may differ from the unedited version. Readers should obtain the final version from the above link when it is published. The authors are responsible for the content of this Accepted Article.

Recent Advances of2D Nanomaterials in the electrode materials of Lithium-Ion Batteries Xiaobei Zang 1,*, Teng Wang1, Zhiyuan Han1, Lingtong Li1 and Xin Wu 2
1 Key Laboratory of Unconventional Oil & Gas Development, Ministry of Education; School of Materials Science and Engineering, China University of Petroleum (East China), Qingdao 266580, China; xiaobeizang@upc.edu.cn 2 George S. Ansell Department of Metallurgical and Materials Engineering, Colorado School of Mines, Golden, CO 80401, United States.; wuxin@mines.edu * Correspondence: xiaobeizang@upc.edu.cn; Tel.: +86-0532-86983350-8623
Received: date; Accepted: date; Published: date
Abstract:The upcoming energy crisis and the increasing power requirements of electronic devices have drawn enormous attention to research in the field of energy storage. Owing to compelling electrochemical and mechanical properties, two-dimensional nanomaterials can be used as electrodes on lithium-ion batteries to obtain high capacity and long cycle life. This review summarized the recent advances in the application of 2D nanomaterials on the electrode materials of lithium-ion batteries.
Keywords: two-dimensional nanomaterials; energy storage; lithium-ion battery

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Two-dimensional (2D) nanomaterials are an emerging type of nanomaterials, which can be featured by using graphene. 2D nanomaterials have sheet-like structures for which the lateral size is larger than 100 nm, but the thickness is only single or few-atoms (typically less than 5 nm). Since the graphene was successfully prepared in 2004 [1], various kinds of 2D nanomaterials have been developed. According to the composition, 2D materials can be divided into five categories including an element (e.g., graphene [2-4]), nonmetallic compound (e.g., oxide graphene [5-7]), metallic compound (e.g., MoS2 [8-9]), salt (e.g., clays) and organic (e.g., MOFs [10]), as shown in Figure 1.
Figure 1. Structure of 2D materials [11].
To date, there are a variety of manufacturing methods to fabricate 2D nanomaterials with distinctive performance properties, including mechanical exfoliation, liquid-phase exfoliation, chemical vapor deposition (CVD), wet chemical process, organic conversion, hot-injection method and so on [7,12,13]. Each method has its own advantages and produces unique structures, which could determine the specific properties. For example, mechanical exfoliation disrupts the weak van der Waals interaction between crystal layers and fabricates high-quality few-layer 2D nanomaterials. But it is not suitable for mass production due to low efficiency. On the contrary, the wet chemical process, including nano self-assembly, 2D-oriented attachment and so on, is a high-efficient method. While it is more difficult for the wet chemical process to obtain few-layer 2D nanomaterials with high-quality. The distinct microstructures, which depend on the manufacturing methods, result in different properties of 2D nanomaterials. Compared with other traditional materials, 2D nanomaterials show many attractive properties, such as excellent physical properties (high Young’s modulus), high surface area, outstanding thermal conductivity and so on [14]. What’s more, the 2D materials are easy to expand because their structures and properties can be simply adjusted and controlled by regulating the surface atoms. In view of these irreplaceable characteristics, 2D materials have broad prospects of applications in photoelectric devices, electrocatalysis [15-17], batteries, supercapacitors [18-19], solar cells [20-21], sensors [22-23], etc. Facing the problems regarding energy consumption and eco-friendly energy utilization, how to utilize the energy reasonably and sufficiently has appealed to significant attention. Some renewable energy (wind and solar energy) are promising candidates, but their applications suffer from limitations of the physical environment, such as location, weather and time. As a result, it is necessary to equip energy storage devices to improve energy efficiency.

sections.heading: 2. The working principle of Lithium-ion batteries
sections.text:

Lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) are a kind of typical energy storage device, which can realize the conversion between chemical energy and electrical energy. Due to high working potential, large energy density and long cycle life, LIBs have been widely used in portable electronics like mobile phones, laptops, digital cameras and electric vehicles.
LIBs are comprised of the anode electrode, cathode electrode, separator, current collector, electrolyte and battery shell. After connecting the external circuit, the chemical reactions on the electrodes provides the electrons. The above-mentioned reactions of LIBs are the intercalation and de-intercalation of Li-ion between anodes and cathodes. The schematic representation is shown in Figure 2a [24]. More specifically, the Li-ion de-intercalates from cathodes and intercalates into anodes during charging. On the contrary, Li-ion moves from anodes to cathodes during discharging. The research focuses on improving the electrode materials properties of LIBs. As is shown in Figure 2b [24], benefiting from the remarkable properties, such as high specific surface area [25], short diffusion distances [26], superior electrical conductivity [27] and electrochemical and thermal stability, 2D nanomaterials are exceedingly desirable in various parts of LIBs [28-30]. The recent advances of 2D nanomaterials in LIBs are indicated as below.

sections.heading: 3. 2D nanomaterials in the anodes of LIBs
sections.text: The high specific surface area of layered structure provides a great number of active reactive sites. This makes it easy for lithium ions to intercalate, which means high theoretical capacity [31]. Together with excellent electrical conductivity and outstanding stability, these characteristics lead 2D nanomaterials to be competitive in anode materials.

sections.heading: 3.1. Graphene
sections.text:
Graphene presents a flat monolayer of carbon atoms packed into a 2D honeycomb lattice [27]. The structure endows graphene with the high specific surface area and superior electrical conductivity. The application of graphene on anodes can be divided into thefollowing six parts.
3.1.1. Pure graphene
It is revealed that graphene can be used as anode materials independently because of its compelling properties. Many researchers obtained pure graphene papers, nanosheets or films through various methods, such as mechanical exfoliation, chemical vapor deposition (CVD), chemical approaches and so on. High quality reduced graphene oxide (rGO), which is full of functional groups, is suitable for mass production, and can be fabricated in different ways. Liu et al. [32] showed a green method of AC CE
PT ED

preparing rGO as anode materials, which treated the as-prepared graphene oxide with supercritical ethanol. The LIBs showed high specific capacity (89 mAh/g) at the current density of 50 mA/g after 50 cycles. Moreover, the conductivities and specific capacities could be modified by supercritical solvents [32]. Unlike the above approach, Fu et al. demonstrated rGO nanosheets by solvothermal reduction method. Owing to the few-layer structure, large size sheet and fast transport kinetics of Li ions and electrons on the interface of electrolyte/electrode, the nanosheets exhibited high reversible capacity of 561 mAh/g at a current density of 100 mA/g and 166 mAh/g at a current density of 4000 mA/g [33]. Mukherjee et al. reported a novel method to fabricate rGO paper with special structures, including micrometer-scale pores, cracks and intersheet voids. After photoflash and laser-reduced treatment, rGO paper anodes presented better performance stability and cycling stability (156 mAh/g over 1000 cycles) [34]. As a conventional method to fabricate high-quality graphene films, CVD method could regulate the microstructure of graphene films. The common substrate is Cu or Ni foil. Wei applied CVD onto the Cu foil to synthesize monolayer graphene and made an ultrathin battery with a thickness of 50 μm. The battery revealed outstanding cyclic stability and maintained the discharge current of 100 μA/cm² over 100 cycles [35]. In order to improve the specific surface, porous materials are used as the deposition substrate. Bi et al. prepared the composite of graphene/filter membrane using CVD methods to obtain the graphene powder. Due to the direct growth on 3D Ni-foam template, the papers possessed better crystal structure and higher electrical conductivity (1097 S/cm) than previous reports. The freestanding papers also endowed the battery with good flexibility, and the loss of electrical conductivity is less than 5% after bending 500 times [36]. Ning et al. reported a novel approach to fabricate graphene papers. They applied the expanded vermiculite as the layered template to prepare graphene bulk materials. Benefiting from the large sheet area, the graphene paper presented excellent flexibility. The papers also showed animproved reversible capacity of 1350 mAh/g at 50 mA/g and better cycling performance than that of the reduced graphene oxide [37].
papers at a current density of 50 mA/g; and (c) the rate performance of graphene paper at different
current densities [36].
Apart from pure graphene, many researchers focus on preparing graphene-based composites to integrate the advantages of each component. The composites show higher electrochemical properties. The recent researches will be reviewed according to specific additive materials.
3.1.2. Carbon nanotubes/graphene
Carbon nanotubes (CNT) and graphene, which are two typical nano-materials, have gained much attention in recent years. As one of the one-dimensional nano-materials, CNT has high conductivity and mechanical property, while graphene is one of the two-dimensional nano-materials with the high specific surface area and electrochemical activity [38]. By combining these two nano-materials, the electrochemical performance can be enhanced. Fan et al. fabricated the composite materials using the CVD method in a fluidized bed reactor. Because of the additive of carbon nanofibers, the composite

possessed many cavities, open tips and graphene platelets with exposed edges, which improved the capacity of storing lithium ion. Meanwhile, the CNTs prevented restacking of the graphene nanosheets and increased the electronic conductivity of the cross-plane. Therefore, the composite showed ahigher reversible capacity of 667 mAh/g, higher rate performance and better cycling stability than those pristine graphene and carbon nanotubes [39]. Another method is using vacuum filtration to prepare CNTs/graphene hybrid films. Byon et al. suggested that, the capacity and energy density could be tuned by removing oxygen species from the composite, which offered a new way to design electrodes [40]. On this basis, Hu et al. obtained CNTs/graphene hybrids and reported that the electrochemical performance was significantly determined by the CNT/graphene ratios. The optimal ratio was 2:1. The capacities remained 330 mAh/g after 100 cycles, which were about 100 mAh/g higher than the pure graphene sheets [41]. Different conclusions were put forward by other researchers. Zhong et al. fabricated single-walled CNTs/graphene materials using a microwave autoclave method. The highest capacity appeared when the ratio of graphene was 70 wt%, and there was no obvious performance degradation after 50 cycles (303 mAh/g) [42].
3.1.3. Nonmetal/graphene
Some nonmetals could also be used to improve the electrochemical properties of graphene. Ndoping increased surface defects, which couldimprove the reversible discharge capacity compared with pristine graphene [43]. Liu et al. [44] prepared nitrogen-doped graphene nanosheets (NGNS) by a novel mechanochemical method via all-solid-state ball-milling graphite with urea, the initial discharge specific capacity of the NGNS was 895 mAh/g at a specific current of 50 mA/g and it maintained a reversible capacity of about 550 mAh/g after 100 cycles. Liu et al. [45] used two layers of graphene stacks sandwich a composite of black phosphorus, which exhibited reversible capacities of 1401 mAh/ g during the 200th cycle at a current density of 100 mA/g, indicating superior cycle performance. Lee [46] and Li et al. [47] synthesized Si /graphene hybrid materials, in which Si provided high capacity, and graphene foam acted as frameworks and electron transporting routes. Hence, the hybrid film revealed superior performance with high flexibility and reversible capacity. Different from the above two groups, Zhang et al. fabricated Si/graphene sheets by combining electrophoretic deposition and radiofrequency magnetron deposition methods, which created many wrinkles and scrolling edges on the hybrid. The composites revealed the high initial reversible capacity of 2204 mAh/g and superior cycling stability (87.7% after 150 cycles) [48].
3.1.4. Transition metal oxides/graphene
Many types of researches have also been carried out regarding composites of graphene and transition metal oxides (TMOs). NiO/graphene Mai et al. prepared NiO-graphene hybrid using a liquid phase deposition method. Combining the advantages of NiO and graphene, the LIBs revealed a high capacity (646.1 mAh/g) after 35 cycles at a current density of 100 mA/g, corresponding to 86.3% capacity retention [49]. The improved performance was obtained by Zou et al. They used hydrothermal methods to fabricate NiOgraphene sheet-on-sheet composite and the charge capacity rose up to 1056 mAh/g at 0.1 C. After 40 cycles, the value was reduced by only 2.4% to 1031 mAh/g [50]. Iron oxide/graphene Zhou et al. fabricated graphene-Fe2O3 through in-situ reduction of iron hydroxide between graphene nanosheets. The product possessed a reversible specific capacity of 1026 mAh/g after 30 cycles at 35 mA/g and 580 mAh/g after 100 cycles at 700 mA/g [51]. Lian et al. used a gas/liquid interface reaction method to prepare graphene-Fe3O4, which improved the capacity retention to a reversible specific capacity of 1048 mAh/g (99% of the initial reversible specific capacity) after 90 cycles [52]. Co3O4/graphene Co3O4/graphene sheets were synthesized by hydrothermal method, vacuum filtration and thermal treatment processes. The composites showed superior cyclic stability (1200 mAh/ g at 200 mA/g after 100 cycles), without any capacity loss over 500 cycles [53, 54].

SnO2/ graphene Zhang et al. used a two-step method to uniformly disperse the SnO2 on both sides of single-layer graphene sheets. When the SnO2 content of the composites was about 60 wt%, the reversible capacity was measured to be 558 mAh/g (71% retention of its initial capacity) after 50 cycles [55]. Then, SnO2/rGO materials had high cycle stability (1346 mAh/g after 500 cycles) through nitrogen-doping [56]. It was deduced that the significant improvement might benefit from the S-N bonds [57]. TiO2/ graphene Hu demonstrated a novel ex-situ way to prepare graphene/TiO2 hybrid papers which display high specific capacity of 122 mAh/g after 100 charge/discharge cycles and excellent cycling stability [58]. On this basis, Etacheri et al. developed a photocatalytic reduction method to synthesize chemically bonded TiO2-bronze nanosheets/rGO hybrid with 80% retention of the specific capacity after 1000 cycles at a high rate of 40 C [59]. CuO/ graphene Mai et al. applied hydrazine vapor to reduce CuO and graphene oxide sheets and then obtained the CuO/graphene composites. The products exhibited the high reversible capability of 583.5 mAh/g with 75.5% retention of the capacity after 50 cycles [60]. The values were then improved. Liu et al. fabricated flexible CuO/rGO hybrid papers by vacuum filtration and hydrothermal reduction processes. The papers demonstrated outstanding cyclic retention (736.8 mAh/g after 50 cycles) [61].
3.1.5. Sulfide/graphene
The properties of sulfide/graphene have been explored by some scientists. Sulfide includes SnS2, Ni3S4, MoS2 and so on. Chang et al. [62] prepared the few-layer
SnS2/graphene hybrid with outstanding cycling stability and superior capacity up to 920 mAh/g. Mahmood et al. fabricated nickel sulfide (Ni3S4 and NiS1.03) nanoparticle/ nitrogen-doped graphene composites which showed ultrahigh capacity retention of 98.87% and 95.94% respectively [63]. Chang et al. fabricated nanocomposites comprising of single-layer MoS2/graphene and amorphous carbon (SL-MoS2/G@a-C), and the composites possessed high rate capacity, high reversible capacity and excellent cyclic stability. The SL-MoS2/G@a-C (1:1) showed the largest reversible capacity of 1116 mAh/g without obvious fading after 250 cycles [64].Liu et al. reported a novel process to synthesize a flexible MoS2-graphene hybrid paper through cross-linking by PEO. It was found that the highest capacity was 1240 mAh/g and the capacity retention reached 71% after 100 cycles. The method provided a new opportunity for electrode design [65]. Zhang et al. synthesized uniformly dispersed ZnS quantum dots (QDs) with sub-10-nm-scale on graphene nanosheets via a facile hydrothermal method, the material showed a superior reversible specific capacity of 759 mAh/g at 100 mA/g after 100 cycles [66].
3.1.6. Salts/graphene
Apart from the above mentioned, a few researchers also explored materials composed of graphene and salts such as lithium titanate (Li4Ti5O12, LTO) nanoparticles. The hybrid materials delivered a high specific capacity and excellent cycling performance (122 mAh/g at a current of 30 C and less than 6% capacity loss after 300 cycles) [67].

sections.heading: 3.2. MoS2
sections.text:
Similar to graphene, MoS2 possesses a layered structure, in which Mo atoms are sandwiched between two layers of S atoms. The structure makes it easy for lithium ions to intercalate, which means high theoretical capacity (>670 mAh/g), so the application of MoS2 nanosheets to LIB has received much attention [68]. However, though the MoS2 nanosheets show excellent capacity, the cycling stability and rate capacity still cannot meet the demand for actual use. That is because its production tends to react with the electrolyte impeding the reaction of lithiation-delithiation. So researchers tried to synthesize composites to solve the problem. Ding et al. reported a polystyrene micro-sphere-assisted synthesis method, the MoS2 microspheres composed of few-layer nanosheets showed higher capacity and better cycling stability compared with MoS2 flakes, as shown in Figure 4 [69]. Hwang et al. fabricated MoS2 nanoplates by a simple one-pot

reaction using Mo(CO)6 and S in an autoclave, which consisted of disordered graphene-like layers with larger interlayer distance (0.69 nm). The hybrid showed the high reversible capacity of 700 mAh/g and outstanding capacity retention after 60 cycles [70]. Liang et al. obtained PVP-assisted MoS2 nanosheets with good cycling performance, high capacity and good rate capability via a hydrothermal reaction. The PVP had great influence on the morphologies and electrochemical properties [71]. Compositing with graphene was also an effective way which has been discussed earlier [65].
Figure 4. (a) Comparative cycling performance of MoS2 flakes (I) and MoS2-NS microspheres (II) at a current density of 100 mA/g; (b) Cycling performance of MoS2 flakes (I) and MoS2-NS
microspheres (II) at different current densities indicated (mA/g) [69].

sections.heading: 3.3. SnO2
sections.text:
Owing to high theoretical capacity, low cost, low toxicity and easy accessibility, SnO 2-based materials have drawn growing attention as anodes for LIBs. The theoretical capacity of SnO2 is about 790 mAh/g, which is more than twice larger than that of graphene (372 mAh/g). However, they are unable to meet the requirement of practical use for LIBs due to the poor cycling performance. Therefore, it is essential to optimize the design and fabrication of SnO2. Wang et al. [72] fabricated extremely thin SnO2 sheets with a thickness of 1.5-3.0 nm, which possessed large specific surface area and huge pore volume, resulting in superior electrochemical performance (a high discharge capacity of 559 mAh/g after 20 cycles with the retention of 57%). Later, large-scale and highly pure ultrathin SnO2 nanosheets were synthesized by a chemical approach and improved the capacity retention to 68%. Compared with nanoparticles and hollow spheres, the SnO2 nanosheets showed better performance. This is because that the 2D sheets reduced the diffusion distances of lithium ions and the interior porous configuration of the products successfully accommodated the volume changes [73].

Figure 5. Charge and discharge capacities as well as Coulombic efficiency as a function of cycle number with SnO2 electrode in button cell [72].
Besides studying ultrathin SnO2 nanosheets, SnO2-based hybrid materials also represent a promising development direction. The SnO2/graphene nanocomposites have been investigated in many studies, which has been discussed in theabove chapter [74, 75]. Various 3D hierarchical structures have been synthesized from 2D SnO2 by hydrothermal methods and good reversible capacities were exhibited and improved cycling capacity retention (516 mAh/g at a current density of 400 mAh/g after 50 cycles) [76]. Sandwich-stacked SnO2/Cu hybrid nanosheets prepared by rolled-up nanotech revealed a stable cycling performance of 75% capacity retention at 200 mAh/g after 150 cycles and a high reversible capacity of 764 mAh/g at 100 mA/g [77].

sections.heading: 3.4. CuS
sections.text: Benefiting from the abundant sources, low cost and simple preparation, CuS is promising to be applied as anodes for LIBs. But CuS shows bad reversible capacity because the original structures would be changed in the repeated lithium-insertion and extraction process [77]. Several researchers have carried out investigations in an attempt to improve the electrochemical performance. Han et al. [78] fabricated novel CuS with hierarchical structures, and proposed that high capacity retention could be realized by changing the electrolyte and limiting the potential window between 2.6 and 1.8 V [79]. In addition to this, Iqbal et al. fabricated graphene/polyaniline/CuS nanocomposites. The composites showed the excellent reversible capacity of 1255 mAh/g, low volume expansion and a high cycling stability even at a high current density of 5 A/g [80].

sections.heading: 3.5. MXenes
sections.text:
MXenes, whose structure is similar to graphene, includes those exfoliated 2D carbide and carbonitride nanosheets. They are fabricated by etching from their corresponding 3D MAX phase, using HF as the etchant. During the etching process, the outer surface tends to be modified by OH and F groups [81]. As a new family of 2D nanomaterials, MXenes have drawn much attention in these years. MXenes possess many irreplaceable properties. For example, Ti3C2 is the first one of MXenes that have been successfully prepared. It reveals good electrical conductivity, low diffusion barrier, low open circuit voltage and high lithium capacity. The theoretical specific capacity of Ti3C2 (in the form of Ti3C2Li2) was about 320 mAh/g, similar to that of graphene. Also, the predicted diffusion barrier (0.07

eV) for Li on bare Ti3C2 was much lower than that of graphene (0.3 eV), which means Ti3C2 could possess faster lithium transport and higher charge/discharge rates [82]. Sun et al. synthesized 2D Ti3C2 with high capacity of 123.6 mAh/g at a 1C rate and demonstrated that Ti3C2 was a promising candidate of the anode material for LIBs. The performance could be improved only by preparing MXenes with pure fluorine functional groups [83]. However, the surface functional groups tended to decrease the lithium capacity so the fabrication of bare MXenes should be further explored by more researches [81].

sections.heading: 3.6. Others
sections.text: Some other studies have also been validated to improve the performance of anode materials for lithium-ion batteries.Ahmed et al. [84] fabricated a composite SnO2/MXene anode for Li-ion battery, and the cyclic performance of the anodes was further improved by depositing a very thin passivation layer of hafnium (IV) oxide (HfO2), which exhibited a stable specific capacity of 843 mAh/g.Li et al. [85] reported a method of preparing thin-film electrodes by direct drop casting of zeolitic imidazolate frameworks slurries (ZIFs, a particular class of MOFs) onto a piece of Cu foil current collector. A high reversible capacity (335.3 and 311.6 mAh/g for ZIF-8 and ZIF-67, respectively), good rate performance, and exceptionally cycling stability (about 95.5% initial capacity was retained after 100 cycles at a high current rate of 5 C) were observed in this study.

sections.heading: 4. 2D nanomaterials in the cathodes of LIBs
sections.text: Owing to remarkable electron transport velocity, high theoretical capacity and excellent structure stability, 2D nanomaterials are suitable to be used as cathodes. Compositing them with traditional cathode materials also can improve the properties of LIBs.

sections.heading: 4.1. Graphene related materials
sections.text:
Apart from anodes, graphene-related materials are also appealing as cathodes. Compared with graphene-free lithium hybrid, a graphene-lithium composite (such as LiCoO2,
LiMn2O4 or LiFePO4) exhibited high electron transport velocity [30, 87]. Zhou et al. synthesized graphene modified LiFePO4 composite by spray-drying and annealing processes. The composite showed compelling capacity (70 mAh/g at 60 C discharge rate) and superior cycling performance (above 85% capacity retention under 10 C charging and 20 C discharging after 1000 cycles) [87]. In contrast, Wang et al. used a two-step approach to fabricate LiMn1-xFexPO4 nanorods and graphene hybrid nanocomposites, which has a higher specific capacity of 155 mAh/g for cathode materials [88]. Chen et al. [89] developed a high-performance composite cathode comprised of nanostructured lithium manganese oxide particles (n-LMO) and graphene nanoflakes (GNFs), which exhibited excellent rate capability (∼75% capacity retention at 20C rate) and unprecedented electrochemical performance at low temperatures with nearly full capacity retention at −20 °C. Kumar et al. [90] wrapped LiMn2O4 nanorods with graphene oxidewhich delivered a specific charge capacity of 130 mAh/g at 0.05 C after 100 cycles with a Coulombic efficiency of 98%, and initial specific charge capacity retention of 87%. Xiong et al. [91] utilized urea as both nitrogen source and reducing agent to synthesize N-doped graphene nanosheets (NGNS) as cathode in LIBs, which retained a reversible capacity of 344 mAh/g after 200 cycles at a current density of 50 mA/g and a high reversible capacity of 146 mAh/g after 1000 cyclesat a high current density of 1 A/g. The transition metal oxide-graphene composite has also attracted some attention these years. Some studies show that the V2O5-graphene sheets (GS) displayed good cycling stability, high specific capacity and rate capacity, but it depends on the relative V2O5:GS content [92, 93]. Compared with a pure MoO3 sheet, the flexible MoO3/graphene film presented high reversible capacity and cycling stability (172 mAh/g at 100 mA/g after 100 cycles) [94].

sections.heading: 4.2. V2O5
sections.text:

As the most stable form of vanadium oxide, V2O5 has aroused considerable interest because of its high theoretical capacity, good reversibility, abundant sources, low cost and good safety properties. The theoretical capacity of V2O5 is much higher (294 mAh/g for two Li+ intercalations) than common cathode materials. The above excellent properties endow V2O5 with a promising candidate for cathode material of LIBs. However, V2O5 suffers from poor cycling performance and low electronic conductivity, and these problems can be effectively solved by preparing 2D V2O5 nanosheets. Wang et al. [95] applied dissolution–splitting method to synthesize large-area pure V2O5 nanosheets with high reversible capacity (290 mAh/g), excellent cycling and rate performance (144 mAh/g at 10 C and 95 mAh/g at 20 C). Li et al. fabricated 2D leaf-like V2O5 nanosheet by a green method, which had the hierarchical porous structure and large specific surface. The hybrid revealed excellent performance such as high specific capacity, cycle stability and rate capacity. The capacity fading rate was about 0.22% per cycle [96]. Liang et al. [97] synthesized ultra-large V2O5 nanosheets by liquid exfoliation technique and improved the capacity retention to 92.6% (after 500 cycles). Other approaches have been tried to promote the cycling performance of V2O5. A sponger-like V2O5 nanomaterial self-assembled from V2O5 nanosheets was synthesized, revealing high discharge capacity of 216 mAh/g at a current density of 20 mA/g and good capacity retention of 73% after 100 charge-discharge cycles at a current density of 100 mA/g [98]. Cheng et al. [99] fabricated a V 2O5 nanosheets/RGO hybrid which possessedthe high reversible capacity and good rate capability. Zhang et al. [100] prepared V2O5 nanosheets/single-wall carbon nanotube (NS/SWCNT) hybrid electrodes, which demonstrated high capacities (370 mAh/g at 0.05 C), excellent energy and power densities (Em and Pm were ~ 555 Wh/kg and ~ 2175 W/kg, respectively).
Figure 6. Electrochemical performance of the V2O5 NS and V2O5 NS/SWCNT electrodes. (a)V2O5 NS and (b) V2O5 NS/SWCNT at the first and tenth cycles; (c) rate performance comparison among V2O5 NS, bulk V2O5, V2O5 NS-Ethanol/SWCNT and V2O5 NS/SWCNT electrodes [100].

sections.heading: 4.3. Li2MSiO4 (M = Fe or Mn)
sections.text:
Among the silicate cathode materials, Li2FeSiO4 is the most promising material with high structure stability, high reversible capacity and abundant sources. Compared with common cathode materials, Li2FeSiO4 presents high theoretical specific capacity (166 mAh/g). As the cathode material for LIBs, Li2MnSiO4 shows good performance, including high theoretical capacity (333 mAh/g), good thermal stability, environmental-friendliness components and low cost. But there are also some challenges such as low lithium-ion diffusion rates, volume changes and amorphization. It was also indicated that all silicate materials suffered from the disadvantage of low electrical conductivity. So it is necessary to keep an intimate contact with a conducting phase [101]. Some researchers have tried to fabricate 2D materials to promote the performance of transition metal silicate materials. Rangappa et al. synthesized Li2FeSiO4 and Li2MnSiO4 nanosheets with an average thickness of 3 nm. The materials exhibited excellent discharge capacity of 340 mAh/g for Li2FeSiO4 and 350 mAh/g for Li2MnSiO4 at 45 ± 5 ℃ with 80% capacity retention after 20 cycles. But

Figure 7. Charge and discharge profile of first and second cycles. (a) Li2FeSiO4, (c) Li2MnSiO4 samples measured at 45 °C temperatures at 0.02C rate. (b,d) The cyclic performance of Li2FeSiO4 and Li2MnSiO4 samples, respectively. [102].

sections.heading: 4.4. Others
sections.text: Covalent organic frameworks (COFs) have attracted growing interest by virtue of their structural diversity and tunability. Wang et al. [103] delaminated COF into 2D few-layer nanosheets, which showed a specific capacity of 210 mAh/g at 20 mA/g, excellent rechargeability (98% capacity retention after 1800 cycles) and fast charge-discharge ability (74% retention at 500 mA/g).

sections.heading: 5. Two-dimensional materials in flexible LIBs
sections.text:
Besides, the strong consumer market demand for portable flexible electronic products has promoted the development of flexible energy storage devices, such as flexible LIBs. As a kind of typical 2D nanomaterial, graphene is a promising candidate for electrode materials of flexible batteries. The layered structure allows it to be easily assembled into a flexible membrane electrode [104]. Hu et al. [105] synthesized highly free-standing CNT-graphene paper through the vacuumassisted filtration. The cross-plane electrical conductivity of the hybrid was improved because the CNTs prevented restacking of the graphene nanosheets. The ion diffusion kinetics and Li storage capability were improved by introducing in-plane porosity through ultrasonic vibration and mild acid oxidation. The capacity of the electrodes tested at 13.3C and 26.6C revealed no capacity loss after 1000 cycles [105]. CVD-graphene paper was also fabricated by Ning et al. [37]. Due to the large sheet size, the prepared graphene could be easily synthesized into flexible graphene paper showing low density and high conductivity. Compared with those fabricated by rGO, the paper exhibited a high reversible capacity of 1350 mAh/g at 50 mA/g when used as anodes for LIBs [37]. On the other hand, graphenebased materials have also been synthesized for cathode materials of flexible LIBs. Zhao et al. prepared FeF3-graphene papers through self-assembly and photothermal reduction. The FeF3 nanoparticles were

dispersed uniformly on the graphene sheet and the porous network of graphene provided open ion diffusion paths. So the flexible hybrids possessed a high capacity of 580 mAh/g at 100 mA/g and good cycling performance [104]. In addition to the LIBs, 2D nanomaterials have also been widely used as electrodes for other batteries. Using graphene nanosheet as a catalyst matrix for the cathode, the lithium-air batteries revealed superior performance with a capacity of 1200 mAh/g without significant loss of energy efficiency after more than 20 cycles [107]. David et al. fabricated MoS2/rGO sheets used as the electrode of sodium-ion batteries. The hybrids revealed a charge capacity of 230 mAh/g and high Na cycling ability [108]. Wang et al. [109] synthesized graphene-wrapped sulfur composites as a lithiumsulfur battery cathode, which revealed high and stable specific capacities of 600 mAh/g after more than 100 cycles. It was also suggested that MXenes nanosheets were promising candidates for anode materials of the non-lithium-ion (Na+, K+, Mg2+, Ca2+and Al3+) batteries in light of their high capacities and good rate capabilities [110, 111].
Figure 8. A piece of the CNT–GN paper that can be bent to any angle [105].

sections.heading: 6. Conclusion and prospect
sections.text:
In this review, we introduced the recent research progress in the application of 2D nanomaterials on energy storage technologies, especially on LIBs. Owing to the high specific surface area, short diffusion distance, superior electrical conductivity and electrochemical stability, 2D nanomaterials have been extensively studied, where they are used as electrodes of batteries to get better properties. Table 1 summarizes the specific materials this review mentioned and their corresponding effect.
Table 1. The materials this review mentioned and the corresponding effect
Electrode Specific materials Effect Reference
Anode
Pure graphene 200~600 mAh/g [32-37]
CNT/graphene 300~700 mAh/g [39-42]
Nonmetal/graphene 900~2000 mAh/g [43-48]
TMOs/graphene 600~1200 mAh/g [49-61]
Sulfide/graphene 700~1200 mAh/g [62-66]
Salts/graphene 170 mAh/g [67]
MoS2 900~1200 mAh/g [69-71]
SnO2 750~1000 mAh/g [72-77] AC CE

Graphene related materials 130~350 mAh/g [87-94]

However, challenges still exist. On the one hand, the production rate of high-quality 2D materials is too low to realize industrialization. On the other hand, it is still difficult to control the structure precisely, such as thickness, doping, vacancies, defects and strains. Directing on these problems, it’s necessary to carry out the subsequent researches as follows: Firstly, more attention should be paid to the detection of mechanism, especially in situ. Through detecting structure changes of 2D nanomaterials, the energy storage theory can be explicit. Secondly, more researches should be conducted to promote the cycle life, security, charge/discharge rate and stability of LIBs. Thirdly, designing a new structure to acquire better properties is also a worthy direction. Fourthly, subsequent studies could focus on the electrolyte, particularly reliability and security. At last but not least, as a key trend, fabricating thinner and lighter flexible batteries is still worth the effort. To realize commercialization, numerous studies are still required on 2D materials. Through this review, we hope to make due contribution to the research on this field.

[91] utilized urea as both nitrogen source and reducing agent to synthesize N-doped graphene nanosheets (NGNS) as cathode in LIBs, which retained a reversible capacity of 344 mAh/g after 200 cycles at a current density of 50 mA/g and a high reversible capacity of 146 mAh/g after 1000 cyclesat a high current density of 1 A/g.

It was also suggested that MXenes nanosheets were promising candidates for anode materials of the non-lithium-ion (Na, K, Mg, Caand Al) batteries in light of their high capacities and good rate capabilities [110, 111].

metadata.abstractText: The upcoming energy crisis and the increasing power requirements of electronic devices have drawn enormous attention to research in the field of energy storage. Owing to compelling electrochemical and mechanical properties, two-dimensional nanomaterials can be used as electrodes on lithium-ion batteries to obtain high capacity and long cycle life. This review summarized the recent advances in the application of 2D nanomaterials on the electrode materials of lithium-ion batteries.
metadata.creator: World Scientific Publishing Co Pte Ltd
